===Filming=== Filming of ''Hannibal'' took place in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada.<ref>{{Cite magazine|first=Solvej|last=Schou|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2012/11/20/mads-mikkelsen-hannibal-anna-chlumsky|title=Mads Mikkelsen on playing 'Hannibal' in upcoming NBC series; Anna Chlumsky to guest star in one episode|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=November 20, 2012|accessdate=December 12, 2012}}</ref> The first season began shooting on August 27, 2012.<ref name="ausiello"/> The series began production on the second season in Toronto in August 2013.<ref name="bowieS2">{{Cite web|first=Kristin|last=Dos Santos|url=http://eonline.com/news/434530/david-bowie-offered-hannibal-role|title=David Bowie Offered ''Hannibal'' Role|publisher=[[E!]]|date=June 27, 2013|accessdate=June 28, 2013}}</ref> Filming for season 3 began on October 20, 2014, in Toronto,<ref>{{Cite tweet|first=Bryan|last=Fuller|user=BryanFuller|number=524208176682774529|title=DAY 1 #HANNIBAL SEASON 3 #Toronto4Lithuania 3|date=October 20, 2014|accessdate=November 10, 2014}}</ref> and some filming of exterior and interior scenes were shot in [[Florence, Italy]] and [[Palermo]].<ref name="3epcount">{{cite web|first=Terri|last=Schwartz|url=http://www.zap2it.com/blogs/hannibal_season_3_molly_foster_will_graham_wife-2014-10|title='Hannibal' Season 3: Will Graham's future wife, Molly Foster, is coming|website=[[Zap2it]]|date=October 31, 2014|accessdate=January 9, 2015}}</ref>
===Cancellation and possible revival=== On June 22, 2015, NBC cancelled the series.<ref name="canceled"/> Fuller initiated talks with [[Amazon Video]] and [[Netflix]] for a renewal.<ref>{{cite web|first=Elizabeth|last=Wagmeister|url=https://variety.com/2015/tv/news/hannibal-season-4-netflix-amazon-1201527355/|title=‘Hannibal’ Season 4? Bryan Fuller Hints at Amazon, Netflix Discussions|magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=June 24, 2015|accessdate=June 25, 2015}}</ref> In July 2015, the cast were released after their contracts expired, but Mikkelsen and Dancy have expressed interest in reprising their respective roles if the series is acquired by a [[Internet streaming|streaming]] service. However, the series has an exclusive streaming deal with Amazon, making finding a new distributor for the series difficult.<ref name=Cast-released>{{cite news|last1=Andreeva|first1=Nellie|title=‘Hannibal’ Releases Cast As Show Continues To Look For New Home|url=http://deadline.com/2015/07/hannibal-cast-released-new-home-1201467144/|accessdate=July 4, 2015|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=July 1, 2015}}</ref> On July 6, 2015, it was revealed that discussions with Amazon came to an end as a result of deadlines set by the service as a part of the deal, which Fuller felt would not allow for enough time to conceptualize and produce a new season. Meetings with Netflix were held, but largely due to the prior deal with Amazon, they also decided to pass on the series, and Fuller confirmed the series was still being shopped.<ref>{{cite news|last=Patten|first=Dominic|title=No ‘Hannibal’ Home On Amazon, Bryan Fuller Says|url=http://deadline.com/2015/07/hannibal-amazon-netflix-pass-1201471391/|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=July 6, 2015|accessdate=July 7, 2015}}</ref> On July 11, when asked to elaborate, Fuller commented that Netflix could not renew the series due to Amazon having the exclusive streaming rights, and that Amazon wanted to renew the series, but wanted an immediate debut, while Fuller wanted more time to work on the scripts in advance before shooting. Fuller also stated that he and the producers are exploring the possibility of a feature film.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/hannibal-movie-comic-con-bryan-fuller-1201538523/ |title=Bryan Fuller Teases ‘Hannibal’ Movie at Comic-Con |work=Variety |first=Elizabeth |last=Wagmeister |date=July 11, 2015 |accessdate=July 17, 2015}}</ref> Fuller stated after the finale aired that financing for a film is being looked into, as well as divulging his planned ''Silence of the Lambs'' storyline and that [[Starz]] could serve as a potential renewal due to their relationship on ''[[American Gods (TV series)|American Gods]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://grantland.com/hollywood-prospectus/qa-bryan-fuller-on-the-end-for-now-of-hannibal-the-future-of-broadcast-tv-and-his-plans-for-clarice-starling/ |title=Q&A: Bryan Fuller on the End (for Now) of ‘Hannibal,’ the Future of Broadcast TV, and His Plans for Clarice Starling |publisher=Grantland |first=Alex |last=Pappademas |date=August 31, 2015 |accessdate=September 1, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hitfix.com/whats-alan-watching/hannibal-creator-i-wanted-to-be-sure-we-had-an-ending-for-the-story/ |title='Hannibal' creator: 'I wanted to be sure we had an ending for the story' |publisher=HitFix |first=Alan |last=Sepinwall |date=August 29, 2015 |accessdate=September 2, 2015}}</ref> Fuller reunited with Anderson to direct a ''Hannibal''-themed ad for [[PETA]], which debuted on November 20, 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/11/20/hannibal-peta |title=''Hannibal'' returns: Bryan Fuller creates PETA ad with Gillian Anderson |work=Entertainment Weekly |first=James |last=Hibberd |date=November 20, 2015 |accessdate=November 21, 2015}}</ref> In December 2015, Mikkelsen stated his willingness to return for a potential fourth season, while also stating that everyone involved would be pleased with the run and success of the series if it does not come together.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/12/04/hannibal-mads-mikkelsen-looks-back-on-season-3-and-ponders-whether-the-show-will-continue |title=Hannibal: Mads Mikkelsen Looks Back on Season 3 and Ponders Whether The Show Will Continue |publisher=IGN |first=Eric |last=Goldman |date=December 4, 2015 |accessdate=March 19, 2016}}</ref>
In March 2016, De Laurentiis blamed online piracy of the series as part of the reason for cancellation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/03/18/hannibal-producer-thinks-piracy-contributed-to-cancellation |title=Hannibal Producer Thinks Piracy Contributed to Cancellation |publisher=IGN |first=Matt |last=Fowler |date=March 18, 2016 |accessdate=March 19, 2016}}</ref> In May 2016, Mikkelsen commented on a possible revival, stating, "It all depends on Bryan. He is the key, the base, the heart. We will wait and see what happens next in his career. But we all know that we can easily pick this up in two or three years, there are breaks in the stories. We could pick it up, say, four years later. If Bryan is up for it, we will all go for it."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://screenrant.com/hannibal-return-mads-mikkelsen/ |title=Mads Mikkelsen Says Hannibal Could Return in a Few Years |publisher=Screen Rant |first=Jeremy |last=Clymer |date=May 1, 2016 |accessdate=May 1, 2016}}</ref> In June 2016, Fuller stated, "The cast is game, I'm game, it's just a matter of finding the right time where everybody's schedules sync up, but I would love to continue to tell the story with Hugh Dancy and Mads Mikkelsen. They're such fantastic collaborators, and one of the most satisfying actor-showrunner relationships I've ever had in this industry. So I would love to continue this story." He also revealed other information dealing with rights: "Two years after the last airing of the show, we can investigate our options [...] August 2017 is when we can actually start talking about it. That's when we would have to see what the rights are for the character and for the story, and see who's interested and how we get it done. I have the story, and the cast is excited for the story, so we're ready to go if somebody wants to go."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://collider.com/hannibal-season-4-bryan-fuller/ |title=Exclusive: Bryan Fuller Reveals Exactly When We Can Start Hoping for ‘Hannibal’s Return |publisher=Collider |first=Allison |last=Keene |date=June 23, 2016 |accessdate=June 23, 2016}}</ref> In December 2016, Fuller confirmed his plans for a ''Silence of the Lambs'' miniseries in an interview on the [[Blumhouse Productions]] podcast, stating, "I think the film adaptation is a perfect film, but there are a lot of interesting nooks and crannies in that book to explore in a television series."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blumhouse.com/2016/12/19/shock-waves-episode-31-for-the-love-of-horror-with-bryan-fuller/ |title=SHOCK WAVES Episode 31: For the Love of Horror, with Bryan Fuller! |publisher=Blumhouse.com |first=Rob |last=Galluzzo |date=December 19, 2016 |accessdate=December 26, 2016}}</ref> In August 2017, formal conversations on the revival had begun.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://screenrant.com/hannibal-season-4-renewal-bryan-fuller/ |title=Hannibal Revival ‘Conversations’ Have Now Formally Begun |publisher=Screen Rant |first=Mansoor |last=Mithaiwala |date=August 10, 2017 |accessdate=August 10, 2017}}</ref>

==Broadcast==
===Episode order=== The series' fourth episode, "[[Oeuf (Hannibal)|Oeuf]]", which revolves around kidnapped children who have been brainwashed into murdering their own former families, was pulled from the United States broadcast schedule at the request of creator Bryan Fuller. The episode was still shown in other countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/04/19/nbc-pulls-episode-of-hannibal-involving-children-who-murder-other-children/178816|title=NBC Pulls Episode of 'Hannibal' About Children Who Murder Other Children|work=TV by the Numbers|last=Bibel|first=Sara|date=April 19, 2013|accessdate=April 20, 2013}}</ref> This was not a result of the [[Boston Marathon bombings]] as some reports have indicated, but was actually decided just hours beforehand, and was more likely due to the [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/04/nbcs-hannibal-drops-episode-involving-children-killing-children|title=NBC's 'Hannibal' Drops Episode Featuring Children Turned Killers|website=Deadline Hollywood|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|date=April 19, 2013|accessdate=April 20, 2013}}</ref> Fuller said of the decision, "With this episode, it wasn't about the graphic imagery or violence. It was the associations that came with the subject matter that I felt would inhibit the enjoyment of the overall episode. It was my own sensitivity... We want to be respectful of the social climate we're in right now".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/nbc-pulls-episode-4-of-hannibal-in-wake-of-newtown-boston-bombings-1200390579|title=NBC Pulls 'Hannibal' Episode in Wake of Violent Tragedies|work=Variety|last=Marechal|first=A.J.|date=April 19, 2013|accessdate=April 21, 2013}}</ref> In lieu of a traditional broadcast, a portion of the episode was broken into a series of [[webisode]]s, which was made available through various online media outlets.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nbc.com/hannibal/video/categories/web-series/736808|title=Hannibal – Web Series: Newest – Videos|work=NBC|accessdate=April 25, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130428150523/http://www.nbc.com/hannibal/video/categories/web-series/736808/|archivedate=April 28, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The complete episode was later made available via iTunes and Amazon Video on April 29, 2013, and the episode appears in the order intended on the DVD and Blu-ray release.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/tv-season/hannibal-season-1/id621056398|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6GGec2r4U?url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/tv-season/hannibal-season-1/id621056398|archivedate=April 30, 2013|title=Hannibal, Season 1|publisher=iTunes Store|accessdate=April 30, 2013|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Removal by KSL-TV=== The series was axed by [[Salt Lake City]]'s [[KSL-TV]] (Channel 5) as of April 29, 2013, after four episodes were aired, and started airing in that market on [[KUCW]], Utah's [[The CW Television Network|CW]] affiliate.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/blogstv/56236258-63/hannibal-ksl-violent-nbc.html.csp|title=KSL yanks violent "Hannibal" off its schedule|last=Pierce|first=Scott D.|date=April 29, 2013|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|accessdate=April 30, 2013}}</ref>
===International broadcast=== [[City (TV network)|City]] picked up broadcasting rights in Canada, where the show is filmed, as a mid-season debut.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.citytv.com/toronto/shows/hannibal|title=Citytv – Hannibal|publisher=Citytv.com|accessdate=December 19, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130613063921/http://www.citytv.com/toronto/shows/hannibal/|archivedate=June 13, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> When ''Hannibal'' was moved to Saturdays on [[NBC]] in the middle of the third season, City continued to air the series in its regular Thursday time slot in Canada.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ign.com/articles/2015/07/24/hannibal-the-great-red-dragon-review |title=Hannibal: "The Great Red Dragon" Review |publisher=IGN |first=Eric |last=Goldman |date=July 23, 2015 |accessdate=August 18, 2015}}</ref>
In Europe, one year before originally airing, in April 10, 2012, the [[ProSiebenSat.1 Media|ProSiebenSat.1 Media Group]] acquired the rights to broadcast the series in Germany, Austria, Switzerland, Sweden, Norway, and Denmark beginning in 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/04/prosieben-acquires-gaumonts-hannibal/|title=ProSieben Acquires Gaumont's 'Hannibal'|website=Deadline Hollywood|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|date=April 10, 2012|accessdate=May 14, 2012}}</ref> [[Sky Living]] started broadcasting the show in the UK and Republic of Ireland from May 7, 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/02/uks-sky-living-acquires-hannibal|title=UK's Sky Living Acquires 'Hannibal'|website=Deadline Hollywood|last=Tartaglione|first=Nancy|date=February 25, 2013|accessdate=February 25, 2013}}</ref>
In the South Pacific, the series is also broadcast on the [[Seven Network]] in Australia, from mid-April 2013<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2013/03/seven-highlights-post-easter.html|title=Seven highlights post-Easter|work=TV Tonight|last=Knox|first=David|date=March 11, 2013|accessdate=April 8, 2013}}</ref> and in New Zealand, the show premiered on [[TV3 (New Zealand)|TV3]] on January 25, 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nz.entertainment.yahoo.com/tv/blogs/b/-/21006097/hannibal-your-new-nightmare/|title=Hannibal: Your New Nightmare|work=Yahoo! New Zealand Entertainment|last=Parkes|first=Melenie|date=January 24, 2014|accessdate=March 1, 2014}}</ref> The series airs in Latin America through [[AXN]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://br.axn.com/programas/hannibal|title=Hannibal: Nova Temporada|work=AXN Brasil|last=Parkes|first=Melenie|date=January 24, 2014|accessdate=March 24, 2014}}</ref> In [[MENA|Middle East and North Africa region]], the series is broadcast on [[OSN]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://osnplay.osn.com/en/TVShowsLanding/HANNIBAL-SEASON-2/ |title=Hannibal Season 2 |publisher=OSN Play |accessdate=November 14, 2014}}</ref>

===Critical reviews=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="float: right;text-align:center; width:%70;margin:10px" |- ! style="padding:0 8px;" colspan="2" rowspan="2" | Season ! style="padding:0 8px;" colspan="2" | Critical response |- ! style="padding:0 8px;" | [[Rotten Tomatoes]] ! style="padding:0 8px;" | [[Metacritic]] |- ! scope="row" style="width:12px; background:#193050;"| | 1 | 72% (43 reviews) | 70 (32 reviews) |- ! scope="row" style="width:12px; background:#A9211D;"| | 2 | 100% (25 reviews) | 88 (14 reviews) |- ! scope="row" style="width:12px; background:#343434;"| | 3 | 97% (38 reviews) | 84 (15 reviews) |- |}
====Season 1==== Reviews for the first season were positive. On [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the first season received an [[approval rating]] of 71% based on 41 reviews, with an [[average rating]] of 7.55/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "''Hannibal'' caters to an intellectual audience that prefers plenty of gore in its psychological thrillers, with a polished presentation of madness."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/hannibal/s01/ |title=Hannibal: Season 1 |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]] |accessdate=May 19, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the first season scored 70 out of 100 based on 32 reviews, which constitutes "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/hannibal|title=Hannibal Reviews|website=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=April 4, 2013}}</ref> Joanne Ostrow of ''[[The Denver Post]]'' praised the series as a "... well constructed, masterfully written piece," but stated "... this level of violent imagery is not my cup of tea..." She also had high praise for the characters, stating that they are "... so compelling, however, that you may give in to the gore-fest."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.denverpost.com/ostrow/2013/03/26/hannibal-a-new-entree-on-nbc/13372/|title="Hannibal" a savory new entree on NBC|work=The Denver Post|last=Ostrow|first=Joanna|date=March 26, 2013|accessdate=March 27, 2013}}</ref> Paul Doro of ''[[Crave Online|Shock Till You Drop]]'' gave ''Hannibal'' an 8/10 and said of the series, "The stab at classy horror mostly succeeds due to excellent performances from the leads, genuine suspense and surprises, well-constructed short and long-term mysteries, and an appropriately disconcerting mood that permeates the action right from the start..." and praised Hugh Dancy in particular, saying he "... does an outstanding job of subtlety conveying how painful human interaction is for him, and despite being abrasive and unpleasant, you are always in his corner and really feel for the guy."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.shocktillyoudrop.com/reviews/173075-review-hannibal|title=Review: Hannibal|work=Shock Till You Drop|last=Doro|first=Paul|date=March 25, 2013|accessdate=March 27, 2013}}</ref> Jeff Jensen of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the show an A- and called it "... finely acted, visually scrumptious, and deliciously subversive."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20685801,00.html|title=TV Review – Hannibal (2013)|work=Entertainment Weekly|last=Jensen|first=Jeff|date=March 28, 2013|accessdate=March 29, 2013}}</ref>
Brian Lowry of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' said ''Hannibal'' is "... the tastiest drama the network has introduced in awhile," and had particular praise for the central trio of Dancy, Mikkelsen and Fishburne.<ref name="variety">{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/reviews/hannibal-nbc-bryan-fuller-1200330510|title=TV Review: 'Hannibal'|work=Variety|last=Lowry|first=Brian|date=March 29, 2013|accessdate=March 30, 2013}}</ref> Eric Goldman of [[IGN]] gave the series a 9/10, which constitutes a score of "Amazing". He said, "A prequel TV series about Hannibal Lecter has to overcome a lot of preconceptions ... But guess what? None of that matters when you actually watch the show, because ''Hannibal'' is terrific."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/03/30/hannibal-aperitif-review|title=Hannibal: "Apéritif" Review|publisher=IGN|last=Goldman|first=Eric|date=March 30, 2013|accessdate=April 1, 2013}}</ref> Linda Stasi of ''[[New York Post|The New York Post]]'' gave the series two and a half stars out of four, praising the performances and called it "... The most beautifully shot and produced show on network TV, with many scenes simply and literally breathtaking..."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/tv/he_got_great_taste_in_people_gXDDT3ctU2c2SknmUbZoZL|title='Hannibal' has great taste in people|work=The New York Post|last=Stasi|first=Linda|date=April 2, 2013|accessdate=April 4, 2013}}</ref> Jeff Simon from ''[[The Buffalo News]]'' called ''Hannibal'' "deeply sinister" and "brilliant."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.buffalonews.com/Article/20130402/CITYANDREGION03/130409941|title='Hannibal' nightmare assumes diabolical new dimension as TV series|work=The Buffalo News|last=Simon|first=Jeff|date=April 2, 2013|accessdate=April 4, 2013}}</ref> The ''[[Chicago Sun-Times|Chicago Sun Times]]''{{-'}} TV critic Lori Rackl said, "''Hannibal'' is a haunting, riveting... drama that has the look and feel of a show audiences have become more accustomed to seeing on cable than broadcast," and concluded that "It's also extremely well executed... bound to leave viewers hungry for more."<ref name="sun times">{{Cite web|url=http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/19233933-421/nbcs-new-hannibal-has-a-look-and-a-feel-worth-devouring.html|title=NBC's new 'Hannibal' has a look and a feel worth devouring|work=Chicago Sun-Times|last=Rackl|first=Lori|date=April 2, 2013|accessdate=April 4, 2013}}</ref> Alan Sepinwall of [[HitFix]] called ''Hannibal'' "creepy, haunting, smart, utterly gorgeous..." and the best of this season's serial killer shows.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hitfix.com/whats-alan-watching/review-nbcs-hannibal-a-riveting-silence-of-the-lambs-prequel|title=Review: NBC's 'Hannibal' a riveting 'Silence of the Lambs' prequel |publisher=HitFix|last=Sepinwall|first=Alan|date=April 3, 2013|accessdate=April 4, 2013}}</ref> Sepinwall also praised the character of Hannibal, writing he has been made into a believable supervillain without making the police force and others look incompetent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hitfix.com/whats-alan-watching/review-hannibal-releves-a-little-chicken-soup-couldnt-hurt|title=Review: 'Hannibal' – 'Releves': A little chicken soup couldn't hurt|last=Sepinwall |first=Alan|publisher=HitFix|date=June 13, 2013|accessdate=June 17, 2013}}</ref> Reflecting on the completed first season, ''[[The A.V. Club]]''{{'}}s Todd VanDerWerff wrote that the series acts as a corrective to the "empty" violence on much of television and "restores the seriousness of purpose to a genre long in need of it.... ''Hannibal'' is interested in death and murder as a means to glance sidelong at some of life’s largest questions. When not functioning as a cop drama, it’s an intricately twisted serial-killer thriller, but it’s also a surprisingly deep series about psychiatry and the state of the human mind." VanDerWerff concluded that Fuller had taken a series "that had every reason to be a cheap cash-in and has, instead, turned into one of TV’s best shows."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/hannibal-returns-the-fear-of-death-to-the-tv-crime,99265/|title=Hannibal returns the fear of death to the TV crime drama |work=The A.V. Club|last=VanDerWerff|first=Todd|date=June 21, 2013|accessdate=June 23, 2013}}</ref>
Other reviews were less favorable. Glenn Garvin from ''[[The Miami Herald]]'' called it "a fast-food hash of poor planning and worse execution...", referring to the writing as "a mess of unmemorable dialogue and unworkable characterizations."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/04/03/3319648/nbcs-hannibal-an-unappetizing.html|title=NBC's 'Hannibal' an unappetizing fast-food hash|work=The Miami Herald|last=Garvin|first=Glenn|date=April 3, 2013|accessdate=April 4, 2013}}</ref> Matthew Gilbert of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' was similarly critical, calling the series "rank and depressing," and concluded that it is "shocking, gruesome, and, ultimately, hollow."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/tv/2013/04/03/hannibal-creepy-and-empty/4ipunY9GTYtSblPowDvYuK/story.html|title='Hannibal' is creepy and empty|work=Boston Globe|last=Gilbert|first=Matthew|date=April 3, 2013|accessdate=April 4, 2013}}</ref>
====Season 2==== On Metacritic, the second season scored 88 out of 100 based on 14 reviews, which constitutes "universal acclaim".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/hannibal/season-2|title=Hannibal - Season 2 Reviews|website=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=March 1, 2014}}</ref> On Rotten Tomatoes, the second season scored an approval rating of 100% with an average rating of 9.22/10 based on 24 reviews. The consensus reads: "With powerful imagery and a strong, unpredictable story, season two of ''Hannibal'' continues to build on the first season's promise."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/hannibal/s02/|title=Hannibal: Season 2|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]]|accessdate=April 21, 2014}}</ref> On April 10, 2014, ''Hannibal'' was voted the winner for [[Hulu]]'s "Best in Show" online competition.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hulu.com/bestinshow|title=Winner: Hannibal|publisher=Hulu|date=April 10, 2014|accessdate=April 10, 2014}}</ref>
Mark Peters of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' called ''Hannibal'' "an engrossing, psychologically dense show that is also visually stunning... the kind of gem seldom found on network TV." He did however note that the female characters were less developed.<ref name=slate_hannibal>{{cite web|last=Peters|first=Mark|title=Better Than Silence|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/television/2014/02/hannibal_on_nbc_is_the_best_thomas_harris_adaptation_to_date_better_than.html|work=Slate|date=February 26, 2014|accessdate=May 11, 2014}}</ref> [[Matt Zoller Seitz]], writing for ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine heaped praise on the show, calling it "serenely unlike anything else on TV or anything that ever has been on TV."<ref name=nymag_hannibal>{{cite web|last=Seitz|first=Matt Zoller|title=Seitz on Hannibal Season 2: I Can't Get This Show Out of My Head|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/02/tv-review-hannibal-season-2.html|work=New York|date=February 28, 2014|accessdate=May 11, 2014}}</ref> Alan Sepinwall of HitFix continued his praise of the series, highlighting the performances of the lead actors.<ref name=hitfix_hannibal2>{{cite web|last=Sepinwall|first=Alan|title=Review: NBC's Hannibal serves up Delicious Second (Season) Course|url=http://www.hitfix.com/whats-alan-watching/review-nbcs-hannibal-serves-up-delicious-second-season-course|publisher=HitFix|date=February 27, 2014|accessdate=May 11, 2014}}</ref> ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' named it the best TV series of 2014, and wrote that ''Hannibal'' was "the best, most elegantly designed thrill ride on TV in 2014".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.avclub.com/article/best-tv-shows-2014-part-2-212571 |title=The best TV shows of 2014 (part 2) |work=The A.V. Club |first=Erik |last=Adams |date=December 11, 2014 |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}</ref>
The season two finale was met with universal critical acclaim. Gathering a perfect rating of 10 out of 10 on [[IGN]], reviewer Eric Goldman stated, "''Hannibal'' ended its fantastic second season with a thrilling, exciting and audacious series of events" and praised the directing by [[David Slade]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/05/24/hannibal-mizumono-review |title=Hannibal: "Mizumono" Review |publisher=IGN |first=Eric |last=Goldman |date=May 23, 2014 |accessdate=May 24, 2014}}</ref> The finale also earned a perfect "A" grade by ''The A.V. Club'', where reviewer Molly Eichel called it "an entirely perfect cap to this season."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/hannibal-mizumono-205033 |title=Hannibal: "Mizumono" |work=The A.V. Club |first=Molly |last=Eichel |date=May 23, 2014 |accessdate=May 24, 2014}}</ref> [[Den of Geek]] reviewer Laura Akers labelled the episode "simply divine" and stated that she has "rarely found [herself] looking forward to a show's return more".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.denofgeek.com/tv/hannibal/30778/hannibal-season-2-finale-review-mizumono |title=Hannibal season 2 finale review: Mizumono |publisher=Den of Geek |first=Laura |last=Akers |date=June 3, 2014 |accessdate=September 11, 2014}}</ref> Emma Dibdin of [[Digital Spy]] also heavily praised the episode, specifically Mikkelsen's performance, stating that he is "so convincingly predatory...and so simultaneously scary and sad". She also laid praise on the sound design of the episode by saying that "the integration of a ticking clock worked so well not just in the usual 'time is running out' way, but also a subconscious reminder of Hannibal's manipulation of Will".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/ustv/s225/hannibal/recaps/a573251/hannibal-season-2-finale-recap-mizumono.html#~oPAYKL9gX1XuVg |title=Hannibal season 2 finale recap: 'Mizumono' |publisher=Digital Spy |first=Emma |last=Dibdin |date=May 24, 2014 |accessdate=September 11, 2014}}</ref> ''[[TV Guide]]'' named it the best TV episode of 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/special/best-of-year-2014/PhotoGallery/Best-TV-Episodes-2014-1091005/1091346 |title=The Best TV Episodes of 2014 |work=TV Guide |accessdate=January 1, 2015}}</ref>
====Season 3==== Season 3 of ''Hannibal'' received critical acclaim. On Rotten Tomatoes, season 3 has an approval rating of 97% with an average rating of 8.89/10 based on 35 reviews. The site's consensus reads: "Bryan Fuller serves up another delightfully demented season of ''Hannibal'', featuring a hearty helping of gorgeous gore, paired with a sweet side of twisted humor."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/hannibal/s03/ |title=Hannibal: Season 3 |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]] |accessdate=May 19, 2018}}</ref> On Metacritic, the season has a score of 84 out of 100 based on 15 reviews, indicating "universal acclaim".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/hannibal/season-3 |title=Hannibal - Season 3 Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=June 4, 2015}}</ref> Joshua Rivera of ''[[Business Insider]]'' stated that "''Hannibal'' is a show that puts all of its chips on the table, blows up that table, and then builds something even more fascinating from what remains", and hailed it as one of the best shows on television.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/hannibal-season-3-review-2015-6 |title=Season 3 of 'Hannibal' continues to be one of the best shows on TV |work=Business Insider |first=Joshua |last=Rivera |date=June 2, 2015 |accessdate=June 3, 2015}}</ref> Dominic Patten of ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]'' also gave the first few episodes positive reviews also stating the show returns better than ever.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2015/06/hannibal-season-3-review-hugh-dancy-mads-mikkelsen-nbc-1201436654/ |title=‘Hannibal’ Season 3 Review: More To Savor With Return Of NBC Series |website=Deadline Hollywood |first=Dominic |last=Patten |date=June 2, 2015 |accessdate=June 3, 2015}}</ref> In addition, the acting of Mads Mikkelsen and Gillian Anderson were particularly praised, with [[Bloody Disgusting]] writing, "Gillian Anderson's performance pushes Mads Mikkelsen in ways never thought possible," while also giving praise to creator and writer Bryan Fuller saying he creates "meticulously detailed scripts that define his characters in completely unpredictable ways." The review concludes by stating season 3 "re-establishes ''Hannibal'' as the best horror show on television."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/reviews/3346848/tv-review-hannibal-season-three-deliciously-different/ |title=[TV Review] ‘Hannibal’ Season Three Is Deliciously Different |publisher=Bloody Disgusting |first=Zac |last=Thompson |date=May 28, 2015 |accessdate=June 3, 2015}}</ref> Chris Cabin of ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' gave it a very positive review, with four stars, and wrote that season 3 is "even more incisively and ambitiously written than the last season, and sporting the most radically expressive imagery currently on television."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/tv/review/hannibal-season-three |title=Hannibal: Season Three |work=Slant Magazine |first=Chris |last=Cabin |date=June 2, 2015 |accessdate=June 3, 2015}}</ref> [[Jeff Jensen]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' rated it an "A-" and wrote, "''Hannibal'' remains the most engrossing (and gross) serial-killer drama on television, and the most beautiful."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/05/21/hannibal-ew-review|title=''Hannibal'': EW review |work=Entertainment Weekly |first=Jeff |last=Jensen |date=May 21, 2015 |accessdate=June 3, 2015}}</ref>

==Home media releases== The first season, including all 13 episodes, was released on Blu-ray and DVD in region 2 on September 2, 2013,<ref name="r2 dvd">{{Cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00CSVD1O6/|title=Hannibal – Season 1 (Blu-ray) (2013)|publisher=Amazon.co.uk|accessdate=May 31, 2013}}</ref> in region 1 on September 24, 2013,<ref name="r1 dvd"/> and in region 4 on September 25, 2013.<ref name="r4 dvd">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ezydvd.com.au/blu-ray/hannibal-season-1/dp/6143648|title=Hannibal: Season 1|publisher=EzyDVD|accessdate=July 12, 2013}}</ref> The region 1 set includes two audio commentaries (by Bryan Fuller, David Slade and Hugh Dancy on "Apéritif" and "Savoureux"), deleted scenes, gag reel, pilot episode storyboards, four featurettes, and "producer's cut" versions of five episodes.<ref name="r1 dvd">{{Cite web|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/Hannibal-Season-One-Blu-ray/73382/#Review|title=Hannibal: Season One Blu-ray Review|publisher=Blu-ray.com|last=Kauffman|first=Jeffrey|date=September 19, 2013|accessdate=August 16, 2015}}</ref>
The second season, including all 13 episodes, was released on Blu-ray and DVD in region 1 on September 16, 2014. Bonus features include episode audio commentaries with cast and crew, several behind-the-scenes featurettes, a gag reel, deleted scenes and the "Post Mortem" webisodes hosted by Scott Thompson.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Hannibal-Season-2/20109|title=Hannibal – Blu-rays and DVD for 'Season 2': Correct Street Date and Cost, Extras, Box Art|publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com|last=Lambert|first=David|date=July 28, 2014|accessdate=January 13, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402142822/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Hannibal-Season-2/20109|archivedate=April 2, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
The third season, including all 13 episodes, was released on Blu-ray and DVD in region 1 on December 8, 2015. Bonus features include ten audio commentaries with cast and crew, producer's cut versions of seven episodes, several behind-the-scenes featurettes, a gag reel, deleted scenes, and the "Post Mortem" webisodes hosted by Scott Thompson.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/Hannibal-Season-Three-Blu-ray/139101/#Review|title=Hannibal: Season Three Blu-ray Review|publisher=Blu-ray.com|last=Kauffman|first=Jeffrey|date=November 25, 2015|accessdate=December 8, 2015}}</ref>

{{Infobox video game |title = Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak |image = Homeworld Deserts of Kharak.png |developer = [[Blackbird Interactive]] |publisher = [[Gearbox Software]] |designer = |composer = [[Paul Ruskay]] |engine = [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]]http://madewith.unity.com/stories/blackbirds-epic-road-trip |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]]
[[OS X]] |released = January 20, 2016 |genre = [[Real-time strategy]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }} '''''Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak''''' is a [[real-time strategy]] [[video game]] developed by [[Blackbird Interactive]] and published by [[Gearbox Software]]. The game was released on January 20, 2016,[http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/12/16/homeworld-deserts-of-kharak-announced Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak Announced - IGN] and is a [[prequel]] to the 1999 space-based real-time strategy video game ''[[Homeworld]]''. ==Development== [[Gearbox Software]] bought the [[intellectual property]] rights to the ''Homeworld'' franchise during [[THQ]]'s bankruptcy auction in 2013.{{cite web |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2013/04/22/thq-auction-darksiders-red-faction-homeworld/ |title=THQ auction results: Nordic Games takes Darksiders, Red Faction; 505 Games is Drawn to Life |work=[[Joystiq]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=2013-04-22 |accessdate=2013-04-24 |first=Alexander |last=Sliwinski }}http://www.gearboxsoftware.com/community/articles/1029/homeworld-acquisition-and-plans/ Following this, they announced that they were [[Video game remake|remaking]] both ''Homeworld'' and ''[[Homeworld 2]]'' in [[high-definition video|high definition]], released on [[Steam (software)|Steam]] in February 2015 as ''Homeworld Remastered Collection''.{{cite web |url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/1/25/7884107/homeworld-remastered-collection-release-date-price-steam-beta |title=Homeworld Remastered Collection launching Feb. 25 with original games, multiplayer beta |accessdate=2015-01-26 |author=Griffin McElroy |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |date=2015-01-26}} After obtaining the IP rights, Gearbox granted permission for use of the ''Homeworld'' IP to [[Blackbird Interactive]], a company formed by members of the original ''Homeworld'' development team in 2007. At the time, Blackbird was developing a ground-based RTS game entitled ''Hardware: Shipbreakers'', which was subsequently renamed ''Homeworld: Shipbreakers'' and announced as a prequel to ''Homeworld''.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2013-09-02-gearbox-had-no-clear-path-for-homeworld-ip-invests-in-blackbirds-shipbreakers |title=Gearbox had "no clear path" for Homeworld IP |first=Mike |last=Williams |date=2013-09-02 |accessdate=2013-09-07 |publisher=gamesindustry.biz}} On December 16, 2015, the game was officially announced as ''Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak''. The game also became available for pre-order on Steam on that date. Pre-orders of ''Deserts of Kharak'' also included the ''Homeworld Remastered Collection'' for free, while those who already owned the ''Homeworld Remastered Collection'' received a 20% discount for their pre-order of ''Deserts of Kharak''.[http://store.steampowered.com/app/281610/ Pre-purchase Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak on Steam] The pre-order also came with a free copy of the interactive Expedition Guide, a [[downloadable content|DLC]] companion application to the game, which details the history of Kharak and its society, the expedition and its purpose, technical data on the vehicles used by the Coalition and the Gaalsien, and a behind-the-scenes look at Blackbird's founding and the eventual progression from ''Hardware: Shipbreakers'' to ''Deserts of Kharak''. It became available for purchase on Steam, along with the game's soundtrack by [[Paul Ruskay]] (who also composed the soundtracks for all of the previous ''Homeworld'' games), on the day the game launched.[http://www.gearboxsoftware.com/community/articles/1461/homeworld-deserts-of-kharak-expedition-guide Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak Expedition Guide - Gearbox Software][http://store.steampowered.com/app/433240/ Deserts of Kharak Expedition Guide on Steam][http://store.steampowered.com/app/436550/ Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak - Soundtrack on Steam] On 15 March 2016, the Soban Fleet Pack was announced as ''Deserts of Kharak''{{'}}s first in-game DLC pack, adding Kiith Soban as a playable faction in Skirmish and Multiplayer modes. Kiith Soban is a subfaction of the Northern Coalition, but with a number of unique differences, including their own version of the Carrier, Battlecruiser, Baserunner, and Railgun vehicles. The pack is available as of 22 March 2016.[http://store.steampowered.com/app/433241 Soban Fleet Pack on Steam] A second DLC pack introduced the Khaaneph faction, clanless scavengers from Kharak's southern deserts who use salvaged Gaalsien technology. The Khaaneph fleet pack was released on 26 April 2016.[http://store.steampowered.com/app/433242/ Khaaneph Fleet Pack on Steam] ==Plot== The game is set on the desert planet of Kharak, the home-in-exile of the Kushan (Hiigaran) people, 106 years prior to the events of ''Homeworld''. Kharak is a dying world, the desert growing larger with each passing year, and the Kushan clans regularly wage war amongst one another. Then a satellite detects an object in the Great Banded Desert, known as the Jaraci Object, or the "primary anomaly". An expedition had been sent by the Coalition of the Northern Kiithid, a group of Kushan clans from the northern polar region of Kharak, but had disappeared in the desert four years earlier; the in-game campaign centers around a second expedition, and its chief science officer, Rachel S'jet.[http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/01/13/watch-the-first-homeworld-deserts-of-kharak-gameplay Watch the First Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak Gameplay - IGN] Rachel's expedition, centered around the Kiith S'jet land carrier ''Kapisi'', departs from Epsilon Base in the Kharakian desert. Shortly after the expedition departs, however, Kiith Gaalsien (a group of religious zealots exiled from mainstream Kharakian society) attack and destroy a number of Coalition bases, including Epsilon, and lay siege to the city of Tiir, the planetary capital. The Gaalsien then attack the ''Kapisi'' at a S'jet base known as the Boneyard, while the ''Kapisi'' is undergoing final outfitting for desert operations. A masked Gaalsien commander named Khagaan declares that the Coalition's use of satellites and other space-based technology violates the law of the Great Maker, Sajuuk, and the Gaalsien declare war on the Coalition. Escaping from the Boneyard under cover of a sandstorm, the ''Kapisi'' searches for their sister ship, the Kiith Siidim carrier ''Sakala'', which also escaped its base after a Gaalsien attack. In a region called Hell's Gate, the expedition stumbles upon the wreck of a previously launched S'jet carrier, the ''Ifriit Naabal'', the flagship of the first expedition four years earlier; Rachel's elder brother Jacob had been first officer of the carrier, which recovered an artifact from the wreckage of a space-going vessel called the ''Kalash''. The expedition moves in to salvage more artifacts from the ''Kalash'', but come under attack from superior Gaalsien forces, led by Khagaan from the carrier ''Ashoka''. Just as the expedition is about to be overrun, the ''Sakala'' and its escorts arrive with reinforcements, driving the Gaalsien forces off. The ''Sakala'' draws off the ''Ashoka'' while the ''Kapisi'' attacks the Gaalsien resource operations, but the Gaalsien carrier changes course to attack the ''Kapisi'' and its escorts. Despite the Gaalsien carrier's defenses and EMP weaponry, the Coalition forces engage and destroy the ''Ashoka''. Approaching the edge of Gaalsien territory, the two carriers assault a Gaalsien fortress, again using the ''Sakala'' to draw off the base's defenders while the ''Kapisi'' attacks the resource operations. Accessing the Gaalsien database, Rachel discovers that her brother had survived for years in Gaalsien custody, and that the Gaalsien believe the Jaraci Object to be the mythical Khar-Toba, the "First City" and origin of Kushan civilization. The Gaalsien leader, the K'Had Sajuuk, believes he will become ruler of all Kharak if he enters the temple of Khar-Toba. Along the way, the expedition also discovers a number of shipwrecks that are largely intact in spite of their age and conditions in the desert, and Rachel theorizes that they in fact materialized inside solid rock (referencing the hyperspace abilities of vessels by the time of ''Homeworld''), having been forcibly intercepted by the power contained within the Jaraci Object site. Making their way through a narrow canyon into a region the Gaalsien call the "Dreamlands", the ''Kapisi'' and the ''Sakala'' engage and destroy two Gaalsien carriers, and fight their way to a high plateau in order to obtain critical supplies via airborne cargo landers from their leaders in Tiir. As the K'Had Sajuuk's forces approach the primary anomaly, a weapons satellite opens fire on them from orbit; Rachel leaves to investigate the source of the signal that triggered the satellite, as the ''Kapisi'' holds its ground against enemy forces on the plateau in order to secure a runway for the landers. Just as the Coalition forces gain the upper hand, however, the Siidim forces betray them, opening fire on the S'jet cargo landers; the Siidim, long-time enemies of the Gaalsien, declare that they alone were of divine origin and would "purify" the desert, and that Khar-Toba and its secrets were theirs to claim. Rachel discovers that the signal that triggered the orbital satellite was from a Taiidan carrier, which crashed on the surface after deploying the weapon; Jacob used the transponder to trigger the satellite himself before dying of starvation and exposure. Rachel escapes the wreck with the transponder and makes a rendezvous with the ''Kapisi'', which engages and destroys the ''Sakala'' and its escort forces. With the Siidim defeated, Rachel travels ahead of the expedition, discovering that Khar-Toba is in fact an ancient starship, surrounded by an ancient city buried in the sand. The expedition sets up a scanner network around the wreck to better direct the Taiidan weapon satellite in orbit, and face the K'Had Sajuuk, commanding a unique flagship-style carrier. The Coalition forces destroy the Gaalsien flagship in a heated battle; as his ship is consumed in the explosion, the K'Had Sajuuk warns that Kharak would be destroyed by fire from the sky (prophetically referencing the events of ''Homeworld'') as a result of the Coalition's actions. At the end, Rachel reflects that her brother had believed the salvation of their people to be found in the desert as the scene pans out from Khar-Toba towards the night sky, and the future that would await the Kushan in the century to come. ===Factions=== Unlike the previous games, which had two separate races, all of the factions in ''Deserts of Kharak'' are Kushan, but have distinct looks from one another, and also work differently. The campaign centers around the Coalition (the player's faction) and Kiith Gaalsien; two other groups, Kiith Soban and the Khaaneph, were added in [[downloadable content|DLC packs]] as playable factions (in addition to the originals) for Skirmish and Multiplayer modes. ;Coalition of the Northern Kiithid :A loose [[Military alliance|alliance]] of clans from the northern polar regions of Kharak, based in the planetary capital of Tiir, which were responsible for Kharak's spaceflight program and the discovery of the Jaraci Object. The clans involved are based largely on what vehicle designs they provide to the expedition forces; they include S'jet (the command carrier, its production facilities, and its launched aircraft), Soban (armored attack vehicles), Naabal (heavy ordinance and Baserunners), Manaan (light attack vehicles), and Somtaaw (salvagers).''Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak'' Expedition Guide, Section 7.0: "Vehicle Manifest" The Coalition makes extensive use of wheeled and tracked vehicles, heavy armor, and deployable technologies such as portable scanners, turrets, and mines, deployed by the Baserunner vehicles. Their tactics are described by the developers as being similar to the Greek [[phalanx]] and [[Cold War]]-era vehicle tactics, both of which required total commitment to battle.[http://blackbirdinteractive.com/2016/01/19/coalition-faction-overview/ Deserts of Kharak Coalition Faction Overview - Blackbird Interactive] ;Kiith Gaalsien :A renegade clan dedicated to Sajuuk, the Great Maker Whose Hand Shapes What Is. Unlike the other religious clans, the Gaalsien preached harsh punishments against those who violated Sajuuk's law. Four hundred years before the events in ''Deserts of Kharak'', the Gaalsien were declared outlaws after destroying the city of Saju-ka, killing thousands.''Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak'' Expedition Guide, Section 4.0: "Kharakid Social Systems" Well-adapted to residing in the deep desert, the Gaalsien use hover technology for their vehicles, and rely on speed and hit-and-run tactics, resulting in their vehicles being less armored than the Coalition forces. The Gaalsien also make use of railguns and self-repairing technology, recovered from wrecks in the desert. Tactically, they are described as being similar to the [[Mongol military tactics and organization|Mongol hordes]], relying on mobility and probing for weaknesses before attacking, and the modern [[United States Armed Forces]], using advanced technology to fight an opponent without fully committing.[http://blackbirdinteractive.com/2016/01/20/gaalsien-faction/ Gaalsien Faction - Blackbird Interactive] ;Kiith Soban :A clan belonging to the Coalition, which provided most of the heavy military hardware for the expedition forces. Known as the "Grey Brotherhood", the Sobani are a [[mercenary]] kiith formed from the remnants of a clan destroyed by rivals centuries before, eventually becoming one of the most feared warrior clans on Kharak. Their vehicles are nearly identical to those of the greater Coalition, with some notable exceptions - the Sobani place greater emphasis on railguns, and both their Carrier and Battlecruiser vehicles are equipped with these weapons over the standard heavy cannons. ;Khaaneph :A group of clanless scavengers from Kharak's southern deserts, descended from survivors of clans destroyed in the Heresy Wars between Kiith Gaalsien and Kiith Siidim, hundreds of years prior to ''Deserts of Kharak''. "Khaaneph" is the Gaalsien word for "[[atheism|godless]]"; while the Coalition clans are seen as followers of "false gods" due to their emphasis on science over religion, the Khaaneph believe in nothing at all, save for their own survival. They often raid desert settlements and supply caravans, utilizing every last scrap of resources they can muster - even [[cannibalism|consuming the corpses of the dead]]. They use salvaged Gaalsien technology (particularly in the use of [[hovercraft]]), combined with heavy armor plating; the Khaaneph Carrier can also provide speed boosts not only for itself, but for all vehicles in a certain radius around it. They make extensive use of siege weapons, missiles, and other explosive devices. ===Spin-off=== ''Deserts of Kharak'' is a spin-off, in that it deviates from the backstory included with the original ''Homeworld'' in the form of the ''Homeworld Manual: Historical + Technical Briefing'' booklet. The latter maintains that Kiith Gaalsien self-destructed and was reduced to the status of myth centuries before the discovery of Khar-Toba{{Cite book |title=Homeworld Manual: Historical + Technical Briefing |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |page=24 |quote=Military expeditions to track them down once and for all have always failed, and a certain mythology has grown up around them -- as if there is a nagging suspicion in the minds of modern Khiraki that the only way Kiith Gaalsien could have survived is if they really did have the grace of Sajuuk.}} and clans had long ceased any serious military conflict.{{Cite book|title=Homeworld Manual: Historical + Technical Briefing|publisher=Sierra Entertainment|page=2|quote=In 810, with all factions exhausted and falling from internal anarchy, a small clan emerged from hiding from the settlement at Tiir. [~snip~] within 20 years Tiir was the new capital and the Age of Reason had begun.}} == Reception == {{Video game reviews | GR = 79.39% | MC = 79/100 | Destruct = 7.5/10{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/review-homeworld-deserts-of-kharak-335091.phtml|title=Review: Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak |author=Patrick Hancock |work=[[Destructoid]]|date=2016-01-20|accessdate=2016-01-24}} | rev1 = [[Hardcore Gamer]] | rev1Score = 4/5{{cite web|url=http://www.hardcoregamer.com/2016/01/22/review-homeworld-deserts-of-kharak/188628/|title=Review: Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak |work=[[Hardcore Gamer]]|first=Mark|last= Steighner |date= 22 January 2016|accessdate=2016-01-24}} }} ''Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak'' has received "generally favorable" reviews from critics, scoring 79/100 on [[Metacritic]],{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/homeworld-deserts-of-kharak |title=Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=2016-01-24}} and 79.39% on [[GameRankings]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/pc/184438-homeworld-deserts-of-kharak/index.html |title=Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak |publisher=GameRankings |accessdate=2016-01-24}} Mark Steighner of [[Hardcore Gamer]] gave the game a 4 out of 5 saying, "''Homeworld: Desert of Kharak'' is an accessible and well-made strategy game with outstanding production values and a legitimate claim to being part of the legendary franchise." Patrick Hancock from [[Destructoid]] rated the game a 7.5/10 saying, "the campaign is well executed for veterans and newbies alike, proving that over a decade without Homeworld is far too long." [[IGN]] awarded it a score of 8.8 out of 10, calling it a "deep, exciting, varied RTS with all the right tools."http://uk.ign.com/articles/2016/01/23/homeworld-deserts-of-kharak-review Zach Turnbull from GoneWithTheWin rated the game a 8/10 saying, "A good, if not ground-breaking, tactical RTS accompanied by excellent story elements. Don't expect to recreate the magic of the original Homeworld 16 years ago and you won't be disappointed.".{{cite web|url=http://gonewiththewin.com/homeworld-deserts-of-kharak-review/ |title=Review: Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak Review |publisher=GoneWithTheWin |accessdate=2016-02-01}} {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.desertsofkharak.com}} {{Homeworld}} {{Gearbox Software}} [[Category:2016 video games]] [[Category:Gearbox Software games]] [[Category:Homeworld (video game series)]] [[Category:Real-time strategy video games]] [[Category:Unity (game engine) games]] [[Category:Video game prequels]] [[Category:Video games developed in Canada]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:MacOS games]]

{{More footnotes|date=May 2011}} An '''in-joke''', also known as an '''inside joke''' or a '''private joke''', is a [[joke]] whose [[humour]] is understandable only to members of an [[ingroup]], that is, people who are ''in'' a particular social group, occupation, or other community of shared interest. It is an [[wikt:esoteric|esoteric]] joke that is humorous only to those who are aware of the circumstances behind it.
In-jokes may exist within a small social clique, such as a group of friends, or extend to an entire profession such as the [[film]] or [[professional wrestling]] industries, or a particular sporting field or chess team. Ethnic or religious groups usually have their own in-jokes.<ref>[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/tm_headline=are-the-welsh-really-funny-&method=full&objectid=17932085&siteid=50082-name_page.html Wales Online: "Are the Welsh Really Funny?", 14 October 2006. Retrieved 6 September 2012.]</ref>
==Philosophy== In-jokes are cryptic allusions to shared [[common ground (communication technique)|common ground]] that act as triggers; only those who have shared the common ground provide an appropriate response.<ref>{{cite book|title=Communication and Group Decision Making|author=Randy Y. Hirokawa and [[Marshall Scott Poole]]|pages=96|year=1996|publisher=Sage Publications Inc|isbn=076190462X}}</ref> An in-joke works to build community, sometimes at the expense of outsiders. Part of the power of an in-joke is that its audience knows that there are those who do not understand the joke.<ref>{{cite book|title=Who Rides the Beast?: Prophetic Rivalry and the Rhetoric of Crisis in the Churches of the Apocalypse|author=Paul Brooks Duff|pages=81|year=2001|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=019513835X}}</ref>
An in-joke can also be used as a [[subtext]], where people in the know may find humour in something not explicitly spoken. They may even apologize for doing so to a [[rookie]], directly or indirectly stating that what they were laughing at was an in-joke.<ref>{{cite book|title=Acting Your Dreams: Use Acting Techniques to Interpret Your Dreams|author=Ben Tousey|pages=118–119|year=2003|publisher=Ben Tousey|isbn=1-4140-0542-3}}</ref>
==Computer industry== In the computer industry some computer programmers hide in-jokes within the code of [[software]] in the form of [[Easter egg (media)|Easter egg]]s, i.e., hidden content that can be revealed only by following a specific sequence of inputs. Easter eggs is a way for software developers to put their "signature" on the program, especially in video games, originally during times when they received little or no credit from their employer for their work.
The ''[[Jargon File]]'' is a [[glossary]] of [[Hacking (innovation)|hacker]] [[slang]], much of which is in-jokes or is based on in-jokes.

{{for|the class of ferries formerly operating in Sydney|Sydney JetCats}} '''JetCat''' is a young female superhero who "flies like a jet, and fights like a cat", created by [[Jay Stephens]] (of [[Tutenstein]] and [[The Secret Saturdays]] fame), who first appeared in the weekly comic strip "Oddville!"beginning in 1994. The character resurfaced as the star of the 1997 Dark Horse Comics mini-series, "The Land Of Nod", which was later collected as the multiple Eisner-Award nominated 'The Land Of Nod Rockabye Book'. Jetcat next appeared in four animated shorts that aired in the third and final season of [[Nickelodeon]]'s [[KaBlam!]].,<ref name=jjj>{{cite book|last=Hal Erickson|title=Television cartoon shows: an illustrated encyclopedia|publisher=McFarland & Co., 2005|isbn=0786422564|page=875}}</ref> which was nominated for an [[Annie Award]].<ref>{{cite news|title=The Urbz|url=http://www.gamezone.com/news/the_urbz_sims_in_the_city_comics_now_available|accessdate=10 September 2012|newspaper=GameZone|date=October 29, 2004}}</ref> In 2001, Jetcat starred in a new comic book miniseries for Oni Press titled 'Jetcat Clubhouse',<ref>{{cite news|last=Beau Yarbrough|title=Crazy Cat: Jay Stephens' 'Post-Ironic' 'Jetcat'|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=558|accessdate=10 September 2012|newspaper=Comic Book Resources|date=November 1, 2001}}</ref> and returned to her original town of Oddville in the weekly comic strip series, 'Welcome to... Oddville!', which ran in the Toronto Star's [[Brand New Planet]] from 2003-2007. This was later collected into the complete 'Welcome to... Oddville!' book by Adhouse Books.
==Characters== *'''Melanie McCay (later Melanie Ilk after her mother's remarriage):''' An elementary school girl who is best friends with Tod Johnson, and can transform into a feline superhero named JetCat. In the KaBlam shorts she is voiced by Ashley Michelle. *'''Tod Johnson:''' Melanie's best friend who threatens to tell everyone about her Jetcat identity. In the KaBlam shorts, he is voiced by Grady Larkin. *'''Two-Fisted Five:''' An Oddville-based superhero team that JetCat belongs to. Also includes Snakefist, Teen Idol, Neon Varmint, and the Suburbanaut. *'''Jumbo Head:''' Star of a cartoon series that both Melanie and Tod adore. A live-action movie was spun off in the last Kablam short but Melanie didn't think the actor would be Jumbo-Head to her.
===Villains===
*'''Vicky Von Verman:''' An unspecified insect-like pest with an [[Eastern European]] accent who planned to transform JetCat into a were-moth. Voiced by [[Susan Silo]] in the short “I Was a Grade School Weremoth.” *'''Bella Kiss:''' A diminutive monster man who was teased a lot in his childhood and speaks in a [[Transylvanian]] accent. He also seems to own hyenas as pets. He is voiced by [[Paul Eiding]] in the short “Project Evil” *'''Moby Doc:''' A mad whale/human hybrid scientist that tried to steal the water from the Wetpark and all of Oddville but was thawed out by JetCat. He claims to be endangered. Voiced by Paul Eiding in the short “Lunchtime.”
==Episodes== {{Episode table |background=#141414 |overall=|title= |airdate= |released=y|episodes= {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 1 |Title = ''Sacred Identity'' |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|1998|9|4}} |ShortSummary = Tod finds out Melanie's alias as JetCat and threatens to squeal unless she does everything he says. The short was originally supposed to feature the Two Fists Five but they were cut at the last minute for time limits despite having the final vocal tracks. |LineColor = 141414 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 2 |Title = ''PROJECT - EVIL'' |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|1998|10|2}} |ShortSummary = Melanie refuses to reveal her secrets to Tod on JetCat for his report so Tod meets Bella Kiss and decides to write a report on a super villain but Bella Kiss demands Tod to tell him about JetCat's secrets which Tod had advertised in order to contact him. |LineColor = 141414 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 3 |Title = ''Lunchtime'' |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|1999|3|26}} |ShortSummary = JetCat tries to stop a whale/human hybrid scientist named Moby Dock from swiping all the water in Oddville during her lunchtime. Tod is also protecting Melanie's mother's homemade chocolate chip cookies from any trouble while she fights crime. '''Note''': This short aired in the KaBlam banned episode "Timeless". |LineColor = 141414 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 4 |Title = ''I Was a Grade School Weremoth'' |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2000|1|8}} |ShortSummary = Vicky Von Verman accidentally turns Tod into a weremoth. '''Note''': The final JetCat animated short in January 2000 before ''KaBlam!'' was cancelled shortly after. This short aired at the second-to-final episode of KaBlam. |LineColor = 141414 }} }}</onlyinclude>

'''James Robinson Clitheroe''' (24 December 1921 – 6 June 1973), popularly known as Jimmy Clitheroe, was an English comic entertainer.<ref>JIMMY CLITHEROE Popular radio entertainer. ''[[The Times]]'' Thursday, 7 June 1973; pg. 21; Issue 58802</ref> He is best remembered for his [[BBC Radio]] programme, ''[[The Clitheroe Kid]]'' (1958–72), a version of which was produced for television on the ITV network under the title ''Just Jimmy'' (1964–68).
==Early years== He was born in [[Clitheroe]], Lancashire, England on Christmas Eve 1921 at 58 Wilkin Street, (now called Highfield Road)<ref name=LT>{{Cite news |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/1405865.research_reveals_life_of_clitheroe_kid/ |title=Research reveals life of 'Clitheroe Kid' |author=Gill Johnson |date=17 May 2007 |work=Lancashire Telegraph |publisher=Newquest |accessdate=24 September 2015}}</ref>, to [[Weaving|weaver]]s Emma Pye and James Robert Clitheroe, who had married in 1918. He was born at his maternal grandparents' house. Within days the family moved to [[Blacko]], near [[Nelson, Lancashire|Nelson]],<ref name=LT/> living at 14 Spout Houses, a row of terrace houses below Blacko Tower. He attended the Council School up to the age of 12, when he transferred to Barrowford Board School for his final two years.<ref>http://www.blackpoolpostcards.co.uk/2012/10/famous-blackpool-entertainers/</ref><ref>http://www.blackpoolpostcards.co.uk/2012/10/famous-blackpool-entertainers/</ref>
An only child, he was named after his mother's brother, James Robinson Pye, who had been born in Clitheroe in 1894 and was killed in action in the [[First World War]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lancs-local-resources.talis.com/engage/showrecord/1287878827167 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120723141539/http://lancs-local-resources.talis.com/engage/showrecord/1287878827167 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 July 2012 |title=Lancashire Lantern community history – East Lancashire Regiment |publisher=Lancs-local-resources.talis.com |date=30 March 1917 |accessdate=4 July 2012 }}</ref>
According to newspapers in 1937 and 1938, at the age of 16 Clitheroe was 3ft 6in and a half. His father was over 6ft tall but Jimmy never grew any taller than 4ft 2in — about average for an 8 or 9 year old boy. Clitheroe's small size was caused by his [[thyroid gland]] being damaged at birth during a [[forceps]] delivery and, until later life,<ref name=":0" /> he could easily pass for an 11-year-old, which was the character he played on stage, in his early films and on radio in ''[[The Clitheroe Kid]]''.<!--<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.JimmyClitheroe.co.uk |title=Jimmy Clitheroe, The Kid Himself |publisher=Jimmyclitheroe.co.uk |date= |accessdate=4 July 2012}}</ref>-->
==Career==
Jimmy Clitheroe was too small to work in the weaving sheds with his parents as he couldn't reach the looms<ref>http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/1405865.research_reveals_life_of_clitheroe_kid/</ref> so at first he worked in a bakery in Nelson on leaving school, but before long started out on the stage, touring the [[variety show|variety theatres]] in Yorkshire and Lancashire from 1937. He was a boy accordionist and also played the [[xylophone]] and saxophone. His parents bought a caravan so they could take him round the various towns in whose theatres he appeared.<ref>https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/uk.music.folk/1VZ33u5XiG4</ref> He made his first pantomime appearance in 1938, alongside the bumptious "Two Ton" [[Tessie O'Shea]]. In pantomime Jimmy was usually cast as Buttons, Tom Thumb or Wishee Washee.<ref>http://www.blackpoolpostcards.co.uk/2012/10/famous-blackpool-entertainers/</ref> but moved into films from 1940 (thanks to a chance meeting with top of the bill stars [[Arthur Lucan]] & [[Kitty McShane]]), into radio from 1954 (initially on the BBC's regional Home Service North, and subsequently on the nationwide Light Programme), and finally onto television (with ITV, produced by ABC Television in their Manchester studios) from 1963.
He also appeared in pantomime and summer season dates and bit-part film appearances with [[Old Mother Riley]], [[George Formby]], [[Vera Lynn]], and [[Frank Randle]].<ref>Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.</ref>
His long-running radio programme on the [[BBC]], ''[[The Clitheroe Kid]]'', which aired from May 1958 to August 1972, is still occasionally repeated on [[BBC7|BBC Radio 4 Extra]]. His catchphrase was "Don't some mothers 'ave 'em!"<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Born in the 60s|last = Glynne-Jones |first=Tim |publisher=Arcturus Publishing |year=2014 |isbn=978-1-90940-978-1}}</ref>
In 1959 Jimmy Clitheroe took part in the royal command variety show and he also starred in the television series [[Holiday Hotel]].
[[Mollie Sugden]] (who played [[Mrs Slocombe]] in the BBC TV series ''[[Are You Being Served?]]'') played Clitheroe's mother on stage in the 1960s and in his ITV television series ''Just Jimmy'' from 1964 to 1968 (which also featured Jimmy's co-star from ''The Clitheroe Kid'', Danny Ross).<ref>https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0163458/fullcredits</ref>
Clitheroe owned a bookmaker's shop on Springfield Road and the Fernhill Hotel at [[Preesall]], and appeared on Blackpool stages for many decades. For many years he drove a [[Mercedes-Benz|Mercedes]] with blocks on the pedals so his feet could reach them. Appearing to be an underage driver, he could seldom complete a journey without coming to the attention of the police.<ref>https://www.blackpoolgazette.co.uk/news/tragic-end-of-blackpool-comic-genius-1-426503</ref>
==Death==
In September 1972 the Clitheroe Kid was axed by the BBC after a 14 year run.<ref>http://www.delabole.com/acrobat/2013/Slate%20May%202013.pdf</ref>
On 30 March 1973 Clitheroe collapsed in his hotel room in [[Plymouth]] and spent four days in hospital.
Jimmy Clitheroe died on 6 June 1973 from an accidental overdose of sleeping pills and after having seven brandies, on the day of his mother's funeral. He was found unconscious in bed by relatives and died later that same day in hospital in Blackpool. His mother had died five days before aged 84.<ref name="Stevens">{{cite book |last=Stevens |first=Christopher |title=Born Brilliant: The Life Of Kenneth Williams |publisher=John Murray |year=2010 |isbn=1-84854-195-3 |pages=412/3 }}</ref><ref name=BG>{{Cite news |url=http://www.blackpoolgazette.co.uk/news/local/tragic-end-of-blackpool-comic-genius-1-426503 |title=Tragic end of Blackpool comic genius |author= |date=2 May 2008 |work=Blackpool Gazette |publisher=Johnston Publishing |accessdate=24 September 2015}}</ref> His funeral was held at [[Carleton Crematorium, Blackpool]], where for many years he was commemorated by a plaque attached to memorial tree Number 3.
==Personal life==
He never married. He lived with his mother, to whom he was very close, in a bungalow at Bispham Road, [[Blackpool]]. His father died in January 1951.<ref name=":0" />
==Filmography== * ''[[Old Mother Riley in Society]]'' (1940) with [[Old Mother Riley|Lucan and McShane]] – as Boots * ''[[Much Too Shy]]'' (1942) with [[George Formby]] – as Jimmy * ''[[Rhythm Serenade]]'' (1943) with [[Vera Lynn|Dame Vera Lynn]]<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0036310/ Rhythm Serenade] at the Internet Movie DataBase</ref> – as Jimmy * ''[[Somewhere in Politics]]'' (1948) with [[Frank Randle]] – as Sonny * ''[[School for Randle]]'' (1949) with [[Frank Randle]] – as Jimmy * ''[[Stars in Your Eyes]]'' (1956) with [[Nat Jackley]] – as Joey * ''[[Jules Verne's Rocket to the Moon]]'' (1967) with [[Burl Ives]] – as General Tom Thumb
